div.head: Deathes proclamation
div.p:
Lorde gaue a preſcript precept and lawe to man, through the pronouncyng wherof, our maieſty was firſt ordeined, euen at that preſent moment, whē he ſpake to Adam theſe wordes: Eatyng, thou ſhalt eate of euery free in the gardē, but as touchyng the tree of knowlege of good & euyll, thou ſhalt not eate of it: els in what daye thou eateſt thereof, thou ſhalt ſurely dye the death. &c. And thus beyng conceiued, our maieſtie remained, not long vnborne, and brought foorth, for the ſerpent oure mother (hauyng once deceued the woman, and the woman her huſbande was foorthwith deliuered to vs, leauynge to vs, as of inheritance, a perpetuall ſtyng, to exanimate and deuoure the naturall lyfe of all earthly thynges, and ſo we continued, but as yet vnperfect
the ſpace of two hundreth & twenty yeares, vntyll wicked Kaym, compelled vs to exerciſe and ratify our firſt force, and vertue vpon his iuſt and innocente brother, Abell, who through the violence of our deadely ſtroke, eftſoones, retourned to a clodde of earthe, frome whyche he deſcēded not long before. And thus haue we declared brefly the ſumme of our higneſſe petegrie.

Now concernyng our ineuitable myghte, and indignation, exercyſed ſythens, vppon eche bodye lyuyng, it would require hundrethes of yeres, to be by vs particularly recited. But that you mortall menne oure ſubiectes, myghte the better knowe, howe feeble your predeceſſors haue ben to reſiſt our ſtrength wee thynke it good, for oure more honour, to remembre a fewe examples,
in the ſtede of a numbre. And leaſt, ye might auaunt your ſelues to be ſo muche the nobler, bycauſe your fyrſt parent, Adam, was created before vs, we beginning at him lette you to witte, that euen he alſo felte the intollerable poynt of this oure thunderbolte. And ſence his dayes, neyther the iuſte, nor the vniuſte, the good nor the badde, the rightous nor the vnrightous, the faithfull nor the vnfaithefull, the humble nor the prowde, the meeke nor the ſtubborne, the myghty nor the weake: the ſtowt nor the timorous: the wyſe nor the foolyſhe: the wyll • nor the ſymple: the hygh nor the ſowe, the greate nor the ſmall, the fayre nor the fowle: the ſwyfte nor the ſlowe, the healthy nor the ſycke. Themperour, nor his peere, the king nor his coūſelour: ye prince
nor his ſubiect: the byſhop nor his chaplain: the lord nor his yeomen: the nobilitie nor the cōmons: The queene nor her maydes: The lady nor her handmaydes: the riche nor the poore, are, or euer were able to plucke their heddes out of our vniuerſall yoake and collar. Neyther man nor beaſt, fyſhe nor fowle, ſerpent or woorme, or any thyng els, poſſeſſynge the breathe of lyfe, in this our worldely kyngedome, but they haue or ſhall taſt the deadly & ineuitable ſhot of this our myghty dart, two only excepted, we meane Enoch and Elyas, who thorough the Omnipotents protection, haue eſcaped our hands, to our no ſmall heauyneſſe. Hercules for all his myghte, nor Sampſon, for all his ſtrength, coulde make agaynſt vs no reſiſtence. Hector the woorthy,
Creſus the ryche, Cyrus the politike, Annibal the laborous, nor ambicious Alexāder the great, whom the whole earth coulde not ſatiſfie, were vnable by anye meanes to auoyde from our dint. Sara the ſobre, Lucrece the chaſte, Penelope the vertuous, Helene the bewtiful, nor pleaſaunte Lais, coulde moue, perſwade, or entice our ſeueritie, to ſpare them any one howre longar, then we had determined. Our maieſtye paſſeth not on pleaſures, we regarde not rycheſſe, wee ſet not by iewels: we eſteeme nothyng preciouſe: we feare not any thretnyngs, wee moue not for manaces, wee ſpare not for pytye: wee relente not wyth mercye, we yelde to no ouerthrow: no dolour troubleth vs nor facte repenteth vs: but as kynge ouer all, wee vſe oure prerogatiue
withoute controllment: althoughe we confeſſe the ſame oure prerogatiue was vppon Ezechias for .xv. yeares by gods mercye reſtrayned, and his life prolonged. We are that dreadefull deathe, a prince of ſuche maieſtye and notable power, that at oure pleaſure wee doo reape and cutte downe euery creature, wythoute any exception. We obſerue no tyme, no manners, nor yeares, no lawes, nor no rightes can wyth vs beare ſway: No region no ylande, no natiō, no people, neither Indes nor Arabies, nor yet thantipodies, are free from our ſubiection. When it is our wyll and pleaſure, our power ſpareth not the pope for his holynes, the Emperour for his maieſtie, the Kyng for his highnes, the Prince for his auctority, the biſhop for his cleargy, the maieſtrates for
their offices: the monkes for theyr cloyſter: the prieſtes, for their Orders: the Iudge for his iuſtice: the lawyer for his pleadyng: the catchpoll for his mace: the landlorde for his rentes, the merchaunte for his rycheſſe: the farmor for his goods: the graſier for his cattal: the poore for their pouertie: the mayſter for his preeminence: the ſeruaunt for his diligence: the freeman for his libertie: nor the priſoner or captiue for his bondes anguiſhe or diſtres. Whoſoeuer ouercommeth, who ſo euer vanquiſſheth: who ſo euer ouerrunnethe: who ſo euer breaketh down: whoſoeuer deſtroyeth, who ſo euer by fortune or manhod atchieueth to the hyghe chayre of honour, yet doo what he can, in the ſpite of his beard, we wil haue the laſt victorye. The yonge luſty gallant
flouriſhyng in the beſte prime of his yeares healthy or wealthy, ſubſtanciall and ryche, beautyfull & amorous, flowyng in pleaſures, araied with natures lineamentes, and ſwymmynge in all earthly benedictions, we can intumulate and incloaſe in a moment, within a filthy ſepulchre, where his deade carcas ſhall remayne, to be deuoured by woormes, and his ſowle tranſported to an vnknowen place. No walle, no tower, no bullwarke, no dyche, no doore, no locke, no force, or fortreſſe, no dungeon, deapth or defence, canne kepe vs out, but our maieſtye wyll vſe our ineſtymable power ouer al men, in euery place. Neither haue we reſpect of nobility or ignobilitie, of youth, or of age: but as ſoone take we the chylde, as the aged, the babe vnborne, as the
ancient horehead: the ſtrong as the impotent: for we doo accompt oure highnes, and ſo in dede we are lord wholly of the temporall world, deuouryng all lyuyng creatures, like as our brother Tyme waſteth and conſumeth in proceſſe of yeares, all other earthly thyngs. Our maieſty ſmileth in our cōceite many tymes when we call to remēbrance, what innumerable people, the tyrannye of kynges, the crueltye of prynces, the extremitye of maieſtrates, the parcialitie of officers, wyth the rygour of the lawes haue ſente here before, & dayly do ſend to our manſion, and dwellyng place, yea euery one yt either warres or the ſworde dooth confound, fyre conſume, waters drowne or ouerflowe, famyne deuoure, ſycknes exhauſt, age take away, or time doth bury: they al we
ſaye, lande at our hauen, to vs they come, one tyme or an other. We ar that onely porte, wherat, wyl they, or nyll they, they muſte ones make their arriuall. And of thys thynge, aboue al other our highnes is moſt able to boſte, that our maieſtie ſendeth al mē thither, whēs thei neuer or ſeldom, make their return, to tell any tales agayne. And that you oure ſubiectes maye the better vnderſtand, that we are no leſſe, but a myghty & terrible prynce, the ſame doth and may euidently appere by our ſeruants & miniſters, whyche ar almoſt inexpugnable, as peryls and daungers, quarels, malicious conſpiracies, battayles, murders, poyſons, ruines ſyckneſſes, edge-tooles, gunnes, gynnes, ſnares, deceytes, and innumerable other ſuche lyke, of all ſortes, by the

whiche men do ſuffre eyther hurt perdition or other damage. What man is there liuyng vnder the ſterres, that would not hartyly laugh if he were but a while in our place or throne, to ſee bothe kynges and maieſtrates vpon lyght diſpleaſures, or for ſmall offences, violently to force our cruell ſtyng, to take away the liues of their ſeruantes or ſubiectes, whā as they them ſelues cannot obteyne at oure handes, for their owne lyues, any ſure patente for ſo lyttle tyme, as halfe an howers ſpace: Yea and oure maieſtie ofte tymes for oure pleaſure, dooth not ſuffre them to lyue many minutes, after the bitter & heauy deathe of their ſaid ſely vnderlynges. And in this one point alſo, our highnes hygh preminence muche ſurmounteth all the reſt: that although oure
fatall vigour is common ouer all men, yet the daye and tyme of our comming and approch is ſo vncertayn, that euery one except a fewe in numbre) as Moſes, Aaron, Ezechias, Symeon. &c. or euer they bee aware of vs, or yet do loke for our commyng, are dayly with our mace ſodeynly areſted and entrapped. It is a wonder to ſee howe all people leade their lyfe without any remēbrance of our maieſty: & more meruayl to behold their greedy deſire of worldly thynges: From the fruition wherof, we take theim vtterly away or euer thei can or haue throughly enioyed any ſmal part or portion of the ſame. Where the ambitious dothe continually gape ſo for honor & promotion, as though they were immortall, our maieſtie vntwineth the threde of his life in
leſſe thā the twinalyng of an eie by reaſon wherof, foorthwith his honour fleeth away, & nothyng there remaineth but a vile clod of donge and clay. Who ſeeth not the proude man, ſo deſpiſyng al mē, as though he ſhuld ſhortly be exalted into the third heauens, where we, in a moment, ouerthrowe his great glory, ſende hym to Lucyfer, his greate graund maſter, in the depth of the helles? Who noteth not, the lecherons and glutton, ſo pamperynge his bealye, and ſeekyng to ſatisfye his luſtes, as though he wer a cormorant inſatiable: where we many tymes ſende hym ſodaynely on meſſage to our brother Pluto, to ſuffre woorthyly with hym moſte terrible paynes. Ye ſee manyfeſtlye the ryche and the couetous, ſo ſcrapynge, and hoordynge, the
worldes wicked mucke, as though they wente aboute, here to ſtabliſhe their dwellyng endleſſe: Where we in a ſodeyne, leaue their dead carkaſes to wormes: & yelde ouer their ſowles to be perpetually tourmented with horrible deuyls. And for the moſt parte, we do ſteale vpon al mē, at ſuch vnſet ſteuēs or vnware times, as we do apprehend ſom ſlepynge, ſome drynkynge, ſome eatyng, ſome dancyng, ſome ſingyng, ſome wepyng, ſome ſorowyng, ſom laughyng, ſome wowyng, ſom maryeng, ſome bargaynyng, ſome byeng, ſome ſelling, ſome trauailyng, ſome reſtynge, ſome rydyng, ſome ſaylyng, ſome huntyng, ſome learnynge, ſomme teachynge, ſomme defrawdynge, ſome pollynge, ſome buyldynge, ſome ouerthrowynge, ſomme catchynge, ſome ſpendyng,
ſome at noone days, ſome at night, ſome in the mornyng, and ſome in the euenyng, and ſom at mydnyght It is a worlde to beholde, how ingrate our commynge is to all people, except it be to a very fewe: we meane ſuch, as ar either ouerwhelmed with great cares, ſorowes, greuous tormentes and extreme paynes, or els to ſuche as remayne in execrable captiuitie, ſeruitude, or bondage: To all other ſortes, we are as welcome as water into the ſhyppe. Lord what a reuell and diſturbance we make, where as wee come once in place. If our maieſtie take our progreſſe to the noble mā maieſtrate, or welthy rich man, thā maye ye ſee verified the ſayenge of Syrake, whyche ſayth: Oh Death howe bitter is the remembrance of thee, to a man that ſeketh reſt and
comfort in his ſubſtāce and riches? for he is ſo vnprouided for our commynge, what wyth the loue of the worlde, the loue of hys rycheſſe, offices, & poſſeſſions, the loue or affection to hys deare wyfe, chyldren, howſes, gardens, and pleaſures: & what with the heauye trouble and woorme of conſcience: the bitter remēbrance of hys former lyfe euilly ſpent: the recompēce and reſtoryng of euyl gotten goodes: beſides that his extreme feare, painfull ſicknes, and anguyſſhe: that yf the mooſte mercyfulle grace of the Father almyghtye, bee not preſente, hee taketh Diſpayre for hys chiefeſte refuge: and in the tyme of thys hys paſſyng, (through oure arreſt) hys wyfe crieth out, hys children wepe, his ſeruantes bewayle, & hys frendes lamente: that there appeareth
nothynge but ſorowe and heuynes on euerye ſyde. Further, his eyes by vs once ſhut and cloaſed, there is by and by no ſmalle adooe and ruffle in his houſe, his children wil to law for their patrimonie, his executours for his goodes, his wife for her porcion and dowry: the ſeruantes for their parte, wyth ſuche thunderynge threatnynges, cruell wordes and countenaunces one to an other eche bodye pylferyng and patching, ſcambling and ſnatching ſtealynge and catchynge, as oure hyghnes beleueth that in our ſayd Brother Plutos kyngdome, there is not the like tragedies. After like manner, when our maieſtie repayreth to the cotage of the poore man or needye, foorthwith he is no leſſe vexed, callyng to mynde his manifolde and moſte heynous offences,
the doubtful place and vnknowen Iudge, whether and before whom he muſt preſently go, to make anſwere for al his crimes, curſes, ſinnes, and vnpaciencie, with other euyll deedes by him cōmitted, in the tyme of his lyfe. Beſydes this, to leaue his poore wyfe, and children fatherleſſe, in penury and comfortleſſe, is no ſmall corſey to his poore harte in that laſte hower: they lamentyng, cryeng, and moſte bitterly curſyng our hyghnes for ſo bereauynge theim of their chiefe and onely defence of poore lyuynge.

Thus where ſoeuer our maieſty is, or abydeth, there is nothing els hearde nor ſeene but deepe ſyghes, loude ſcrikyngs, wofull wringyng of handes, and heauy ſalte teares: For we are named to bee Lorde of lamentation, kyng of all ſorowes,
gouerner of miſeries, & the ground of all kynd of greuous calamities, yea, what infelicitye is there wyth tongue, to be ſpoken or harte to bee thought, but oure maieſtie ſometymes put them in vre and exerciſe?

If our highnes come ones to a conflict or battaile, as we are neuer abſent, we do warant you, frō any ſuche, though there were a hundreth of theym, in ſundrye places, at one momēt of time, thē forthwith there maye men ſee of all ſortes of miſeries and miſchiefes heapes and aboundaunce. Some are ſente to vs fightyng, ſome fleeyng, ſome aſſailynge, ſome yeldyng: ſome come to vs headleſſe ſomme ouerthrowne, ſome clouen to the teeth, ſom thruſt through the hart, ſom riuen in pieces by gunſhot, ſom ſtriken down, ſome troden vnder foote, ſome gaſpyng
for breath: ſome moſte profoundly yellyng and gronyng. So that by theyr moſte hydeous clamours, dolorous ſyghynges, and dredefull ſhowtes, it is ryghte wel knowen, ſene, and perceyued, and they throughly feele, that our ſayd highnes is amongeſt theim, as a bloude thirſtye god, to receaue the bloudy ſacrifices of their woful lyues. And thus from tyme to tyme, hath thinexplicable power & might of our maieſtie flouriſhed ſens the fyrſt killyng of iuſte Abell, hitherto, and ſhall ſo continue, vntyll the vtter conſummation of heuen and erth by fyre. For theſe therfore and ſundry other conſiderations, it becommeth all you oure ſubiectes, of force and neceſſitie, to feare our ineſtimable indignatiō & diſpleſure.

Nowe alſo we wyl let you partlie
to vnderſtande with what ſinceritie we doo miniſter our iuſtice: for ſeeyng that true equitie and iuſtice conſiſteth in equall indifferency to be diſtributed to al men alike without any fauor or reſpect, then dare and may our maieſtie boldely challenge, that there is none iuſter thenne wee. For who can, or euer could reproue vs of parcialitie, ſeyng we execute our force as wel agaynſt the prince as the abiect, vppon the ryche, as the poore, extinguiſhynge the lyfe of eche lyuynge creature, vnder one our law, order or decree & firſt conſtitution. If giftes coulde haue bribed vs, poſſeſſions haue ſatisfied vs, requeſtes ouercome vs, or pleſures haue wo • vs, then are we aſſured, we ſhould ſhortely haue proued the welthieſt the rycheſte and the happyeſt vnder
the ſonne. But oure hyghneſſe neuer ſpared any that euer remayned within the compaſſe of our domynion or iuriſdiction, ſence the worldes fyrſte creation, hethervnto, No not that Innocente and myghty prince, IESVS, the deere beeloued ſonne and heyre of oure omnipotente Father: but euen hee alſo felte and ſuſteyned the myght of our violence, through the faithfull dyligence of Satans truſtye myniſters, the wicked Iewes.

Thus haue we partely aduertiſed all you mortall creatures, our ſubiects, of ye terrour of our inuincible puiſſance, and the righteous ſeueritie of oure Iuſtyce. And nowe ſhall wee brefely ſignifie vnto you what innumerable benefyttes all perſonnes, of eche eſtate condition and degree, doo dayly receaue by
oure auctoritie. And fyrſte, for thobſeruyng of order, we wyll begin with you Emperors and Empreſſes, you Kyngs and Quenes, you princes and princeſſes, and all ſuche, ſuperiour maieſtrates, beeynge our chiefe and principall ſubiectes: If our power were not, wee ſaie, ye, of all other ſhoulde lyue in moſte cares and fearefulnes. For we of our clemēcy, take away your traitours, proſtrate your enemies, ridde you of your rebelles, and extinguiſhe your aduerſaries, reſtoryng your bodies to ſuertie, youre realmes to tranquillitie, your people to peace, and abundance of all thynges: where as if the vigour of our maieſtie were not, they would abandon you from your ſceptures and diademes, bereaue you of your eſtates: caſt you into moſt greuous
thraldom and miſeries. Alſo what gracious good tournes doo all cō mon welthes, and al ſortes of people ſuſtein by our fauorable frendſhyp and magnificēce? Which way coulde the landlorde enioy his landes, rents and poſſeſſions: the merchant his goodes and his merchandiſe: the huſbandeman his corne & his cattall: the crafteſman the profite of his facultie and ſcience: the labourer his hyre or his wages, if our power were not? What matrones vnrauiſhed, what wyues vndefiled, what maides & virgins vndefloured ſhould there be throughout the whole erth, if we were not a rightous reward to thoffenders: What wealthy men ſpoyled, what good men wrōged, what pooremen oppreſſed, what wicked men exalted, what honeſt mē abiected, what
trauaylours murthered: what iuſt men betraied, what officers kylled and reſyſted ſhould there be, yf we were not a terrible ſcourge to the wicked? What religion, what lawe what equitie, what fayth, what iuſtice, what truth, what innocency, what Chaſtytie, what wedlocke, what honeſtie, what Obedyence, ſhoulde bee founde or ſeene in any place, if we were not the goulf that ſwallowe all tranſgreſſours? Nay, what wronge, what iniurye, what diſobedience, what manſlaughter, what theft, what treaſon, what conſpyracyes, what lyinge in wayte, what bloudſhede, what oppreſſion, what extorcion, what rape, what inceſte, what fornication, what adulterie, what witchecraft, what ſorceries, what hereſies, blaſphemies and mooſte deteſtable Iniquityes
woulde abounde and ouerflowe in euery place, if our grace were not the rooter out of malefactours.

No countrey, no realm, no citie, no towne, no village, no hamlet, nor any mans habitation coulde ſtand or continue any tyme vncorrupted defaced, or vtterlye deſtroyed, yf it were not oure pleaſure to ſhorten the lyues of euill and wycked men, and to cutte of the pernicious, vnfruitefull, and rotten membres of all inhabited regyons. Throughe the bountyfulle and beneuolente goodnes of our maieſtie, Religion is eſtablyſhed in his due honoure and reuerence: the Gouernours obeyed in the myniſtration of theyr lawes: the godly are cheryſhed: the meke are ſupported: thoſe that are vertuous are eſtemed: the iuſte are preferred: the honeſt commended:
and al publike good ordres and ſtatutes conſerued. Who can then deny, the premiſſes duely wayed, but that our highnes inuincible power is to all mortall men, a thyng moſt neceſſary: as without the whiche, the whole earth wold in ſhort tyme hee ſo repleniſhed with iniquitie, that euen hel it ſelf (as we thinke) would be the better of the twayne. Moreouer, this inconuenience we coniect would haue ben, and come to paſſe, yf wee had ſuffred all nations and people to haue remained ſtyl on line, frome the beginnyng of the worlde, vntill this preſent day: that tenne ſuche earthes as this is: would not haue ſuffiſed to haue fed and preſerued theym with neceſſary ſuſtenaunce. And nowe for the declaration of our ſundry other benefits, who ſeeth not, how the nearer
our maieſtie dooth approche to the faithefull, the hartlier they doe reioyce: and when wee come, they imbrace vs cherefully: to the poore & oppreſſed our preſence is ioyous: to the captiue confortable: to the tormented, happy: to the pacient in his extremitie of ſyckneſſe, wyſhed for: and to innumerable others very acceptable. And that our ſubiect Iob ryght well knewe, whenne he cried: Wherfore is the lyght gyuen to hym that is in miſerye, and lyfe vnto them that haue heuy hartes, which longe for death: and though it come not, woulde digge it out of high places, which alſo woulde be excedynge glad and reioyce, if they could fynd theyr graue any where. Yea and our ſubiect Syrak reporteth no leſſe of our maieſtie, ſaying Oh Deathe, howe acceptable and
good is your iudgemente vnto the nedefull, & to hym whoſe ſtrength fayleth, or that is nowe in his laſte age, or that is full of care or fearefulnes, vnto him alſo that is in deſpaire, or that hath no hope or pacience? Thus you ſee well howe the commynge of our hyghnes is gratefull to an infinite multitude. Furthermore, ſens that now it euidently appereth, the whole worlde to be almoſt drowned in filthines, and ſhamleſſe maners, flowyng in deceates, and ſurmountyng in oppreſſion: where neither faithe, pietie, peace, iuſtice, reſt, or quietneſſe remaineth. Where mooſte horrible crimes rule ouer al: where the brother intendeth the bane of his brother: where the ſonne oft thirſteth tyll we fetche his father: where the
woman ofte longeth tyll we ſtrike her huſbande: where the man as muche hungreth tyl we catche his wyfe: wheremoſte men ſcrapeth, coueteth and hourdeth: where eche man ſpeaketh fayre, and woorketh the contrary: where chaſtitie is cō temned, and matrimonie polluted: where hunger, thyrſte, ſicknes, impotencie, nedynes, nakedneſſe, pouertie, impriſonment, and ſo many daungers and continuall labours doo aſſayle men on al ſydes: where all kynde of miſeries doo ſo compaſſe all maner of creatures, that none or veraie fewe in numbre, in all their lyues, can lyue one whole daie out of ſome vexation or trouble. Nowe what wyſe manne is there then that ſettyng apart al affections, and ryghtely ponderynge the manifolde cares, perils, grefes,
and ſorowes wherwith mans lyfe is enuironned on euery ſyde, dothe not worthelye iudge our maieſtyes commynge, to be daily wiſſhed for: yea, and thoſe creatures to be three tymes bleſſed, that ſooneſt aryueth at our ſure landing place. Such is the beneuolence of oure hyghneſſe, that we fynyſhe al paines, we looſe all bondes, we dryue awaye feare, and exclude all doubtes. Yea, and lyke as men before (their concepti-and natiuitie) knew no lack, no heuines, no penurie, no oppreſſiō, no diſtreſſe, vnquietnes or trouble: no more ſhal the good fele any the like beyng once paſſed our narowe and ſtrayte paſſage. And as our maieſtie ſuppoſeth in our conceite, who ſo hath once eſcaped the terrour of our violence, he ſtandeth by and by ſafe on the ſhoare, and derydynge
lawghyng at the foly of others his ſucceſſours, whyche had rather be ſtyll tombled and toſſed with the ſtormy tempeſt is and horrible ſurges, in the cruel & troubleſom ſeas of worldly miſeries, thā to prepare themſelues redily to paſſe through vs into quietnes. Thus haue we ſufficientely opened & proued to all you our louyng ſubiectes, the force of our highneſſe, the iuſtice of our maieſtie, & the beneuolent clemencie of our gracious goodneſſe, that (regardynge youre moſte bounden dueties of allegeance) ye might the rather in cōſideration therof, feare and obey vs, worthily eſteeme vs, and humblye thanke vs.

FINALLY foraſmuche as oure maieſtie doth wel ponder and perceaue our owne highneſſe (in this latter age of the worlde) which draweth
faſte to his appoynted ende and conſummation, to be wel nere growne to the latter tyme of oure yeares: and conſyderyng alſo that our myght, force, and violence (by reaſon of our ſhorte continuaunce hereafter, is nowe farre more extreme to all people, then it was at the begynnyng, when Adam, as ye reade, lyued .viii. hundreth yeares. Noe .ix. hundreth and .xv. yeares, and Abraham Clxxv. yeres, where as we doo not ſuffre you oure ſubiectes nowe adaies ye ſe, and moſt of this tyme, to lyue paſſyng fiftye or .lx. yeres, or at the vttermoſt reſpityng very fewe tyl they may attain to the nūbre of .lxx. or ful .lxxx.

Further, for that we throughely perceiue, that ſens our fyrſt creatiō at the fall of man, when he was baniſhed out of that pleaſant garden
of Edom, there was neuer age of all the ſixe ages paſt, that euer did flowe or abounde in ail kynde of iniquitye and abhomination, as this laſte age dooth, whiche waloweth all togither in ſinne and wickednes, and is growen to ſuch miſchief, that if it ſhould long endure, men wold ſcant beleue, there were either God, heauen, or helle, after this mortall lyfe: but that by oure ſeparation of the lyfe from the carkas, both body & ſoule wer vtterly extincte: yea and all hope of reſurrection fruſtrat. We therfore of our maieſties mere motiō, ſpecial grace and beneuolence, wiſhyng the ſafegarde of all, and the diſtruction of none, if it might be, do preſently publiſh and declare vnto you, & euery of you, our louing ſubiects, throughout our hole earthly dominions
this our general pleaſure, precept, and laſte commaundement (beyng the only ground, waightieſt cauſe, and pithyeſt matter, ment, intended and expreſſed in this our Proclamation) that we in the name of our owne Supreme maieſtie and hyghneſſe, doo generally wyll and requyre you, and neuertheleſſe in the behalfe of the father omnypotente, oure eternall ſoueraigne doo ſtraightly charge, and commaunde you, and euery of you, of what ſexe, age, ſtate, degree, or condition ſoeuer ye be, or herafter ſhalbe, immediatlye vpon the recept, ſyght, hearyng, notice or publication of theſe preſentes all delayes and excuſes ſette aparte, wyth aſmuche conuenyente ſpeede and dylygence as is poſſyble, euery one of you, prepare youre ſelues wyllyngely to leaue
thys vayne worlde, and to forgoe the vanities, inticementes, and deceaptefull pleaſures of thys frayle and tranſytorye lyte, makynge you redye and meete, to attende and wayte on our maieſtyes perſonne, where and whenne ſo euer ye ſhall by our auctorytye be ſodeinly ſummoned, cyted, or called: that at our vnknowen commyng: ye may be thoroughe oure hygheneſſe areſte founde gladde, and preſte to paſſe into an other muche better lyfe, replenyſhed wyth al ſtable ioyes and tranquyllytye. Further, exhortynge all you oure louynge ſubiectes in the meane tyme, to fall to repentaunce for youre former euyll lyues, to crye hartelye to the almyghtye, to graunte you hys mercye, to Sacryfyce to hym youre humble prayers, euen frome the
bottome of your ſorye and contrite heartes: to obeye his commaundementes: to ſeeke onely his prayſe and honour in all your deedes: to relieue your poore brethren with parte of your goodes: And to conclude, to lyue chriſtianly, to deale iuſtly, and to paſſe youre tyme vertuouſely, that beeynge once paſſed vs, ye may enter into the glorious kyngedome of God the Fathers dere ſonne, and our halfe brother, Ieſus.

Fayle ye not this to dooe, as ye entende, not onely to auoyde ours but alſo his terrible indignation for dooynge the contrarye, and alſo incurre in the latter dreadefulle daye, the heauye bitter, and mooſte wofull domynyon of oure cruelle Succeſſoure, Deathe eternall.

Where, we aſſure you, remayneth
nothynge, but moſte horrible paynes, inexplicable tormentes, myſerable ſorowes, endleſſe diſpleaſure, ineffable terrour, and gnaſſhyng of teeth, with fyre and brymſtone perpetually bournynge, and durable for euer.

¶Geuen at our maieſties inuiſible honour and pallaice imperiall, Situate in the Ayrie Region, the laſte day of Iune, in the yeare ſince our highnes firſt creation, accordyng to the writyng of the Hebrues, fyue thouſande .v. hundred, and eyghtene.

div.head: Here folovveth fyue preceptes of pure and honeſt lyfe.
div.p: FIrſte, To feare, prayſe, and honour Almyghty God, the eternall Creatoure of heauen and earthe, and all thynges therein conteyned, with an humble and faithfull mynde, that is not defiled or contaminated with fleſhely luſte, worldly deſires or wicked affections, is the chief and moſte principall poynt of perfect vertue or vnſpotted lyfe.
The nexte and ſeconde is, That a man warely take hede to his talke, ſpeeche, or tonge: That he neuer ſpeake eyther blaſphemye of God, ſlaunder of his neyghbour, or any wicked lyes, or vntruth.

And for his better inſtruction, let manne haue alwayes theſe three tymes apointed for communication in his remembrance: Not to ſpeake but when a queſtion is aſked of hym, or when no neceſſitie conſtrayneth hym to demaunde a queſtion: or to enforme or enſtructe any parſon in knowledge, vertue, or honeſt maners to the parties edification, to whome he ſpeaketh. In theſe three only preſcribed tymes, Speche
is better then ſylence: In all other tymes it is better to holde a mans tongue then to ſpeake, for ſylence is the handmayde to wyſedome and prudence.

The third rule or precept is, To be lowly and gentyll of behauiour and maners, that is, To ſalute euery man gladlye, to preſume before none, to contemne or deſpiſe no perſone (be their eſtate and condition neuer ſo meane, poore, or ſymple)

And this rule is ſo profytable to ye ſocietie of mans lyfe, that it wil not only procure, and continue a good name to him, who ſo vſeth it, but alſo to brynge to paſſe, that he ſhall haue eche man to bee his frende, and none to be his ennemy.

The fowerth rule to bee learned is, To abandon and vtterly eſchewe all bodylye luſte, vayne pleaſures, play, and ydlenes, the nouriſher of vices. And to forſee, that thoſe battes and enticementes be with vigilancye wholly abiected & repulſed. For who ſeeth not in fleſhely luſt and delytes, three continuall euyls, that is to ſay, The exhauſtynge or conſumynge of the lyuely vygour and powers, as well of the body, as of the mynde: The haſtenynge alſo of
ryueled age, with the ſhortnyng of mans lyfe. And the heauye and moſte wofull bitinge or gnawynge of that helly ſcorpion repentaunce. Now in pleaſures and play what is there followinge, but extreme folye, waſte and loſſe of that precious treaſure Tyme, and in the ende (for the moſte parte) myſerye, pouertye, and diſpayre.

And as for ydleneſſe, is not onelye of all theſe euylles aboue reherſed, but alſo of a thouſande miſchiefes moe, the very patrone, ladye, and mayſtreſſe, and the readye patheway to Pluto his infernal dwellyng place.

The fyfthe rule or poynt to be learned, is, Daiely with dilygence and attencion to applye thy ſelfe to ſome vertuouſe and godly exerciſe, that is to ſay: Thou muſte addicte thy mynde to the ſtudye and learnynge of ſome ſerious and lawdable ſcience,, or knowledge, whiche maye eyther preſently be a lanterne to thy lyfe and behauiour, or nowe and hereafter profitable to the mayntenance and lawfull honeſte augmentation of thy lyuynge and ſubſtaunce: lettynge no daye eſcape withoute dooyng ſomme beneficiall exercyſe, that at the viſitation of ſyckeneſſe or age,
thou bee not oppreſſed with myſerye and indigence, for the lacke of humayne neceſſaries, whyche wyll then ouerwhealme thee with intollerable calamities.
div.trailer: ¶Thus endeth theſe fyue preceptes of vertuous and honeſt lyfe, wourthye to bee marked, and folowed.

p.hi: ❧Peruſed and allovved according to the Quenes maieſties iniunctions.

div.head: Henry Sutton dwellyng in Pater noſter row at the ſigne of the blacke Boy.
div.p: The .8. day of Ianuary. Anno. M.D.LXI.
